articles: ONS survey highlights pre-existing conditions most commonly associated with Covid-19 deaths
name: ONS survey highlights pre-existing conditions most commonly associated with Covid-19 deaths
first-par: Men, the elderly and people with pre-existing health conditions are most likely to die due to coronavirus, official data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has confirmed.

articles: More than 150,000 self-employed not covered by government support scheme
name: More than 150,000 self-employed not covered by government support scheme
first-par: Some 151,000 started self-employment after March 2019, new data has revealed – meaning they are not eligible for help under the government’s Covid-19 support scheme.

articles: 8,000 more deaths than normal in week to 10 April, ONS says
name: 8,000 more deaths than normal in week to 10 April, ONS says
first-par: Nearly 8,000 more people than normal died in the week ending 10 April, with the bulk of the extra deaths directly attributed to Covid-19, the latest data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) has revealed.

articles: Latest worldwide death stats suggest peak has passed, but not in the US
name: Latest worldwide death stats suggest peak has passed, but not in the US
first-par: The latest figures for Covid-19 deaths across the countries hit hardest by the virus suggest the peak of the pandemic has passed – but the data from the US paints a very different picture.

articles: Covid-19 daily report: Death toll trends inch downwards in worst-hit nations
name: Covid-19 daily report: Death toll trends inch downwards in worst-hit nations
first-par: All the countries worst hit by the coronavirus outbreak – the US, Spain, Italy, France and the UK – have seen their number of daily deaths fall in the past seven days.

articles: Half of coronavirus business grants in England still unclaimed
name: Half of coronavirus business grants in England still unclaimed
first-par: Businesses in Nottingham, Birmingham and Manchester have claimed less than a fifth of the coronavirus emergency support available to them, new government figures reveal.

articles: Worldwide coronavirus death rate rises after US spike
name: Worldwide coronavirus death rate rises after US spike
first-par: There were 7,793 deaths from Covid-19 reported around the world yesterday, the highest daily increase since last Friday, 17 April.

articles: 27,000 more deaths than normal since start of coronavirus pandemic, ONS says
name: 27,000 more deaths than normal since start of coronavirus pandemic, ONS says
first-par: England and Wales saw 27,000 more deaths than would normally be expected between the start of March, when the coronavirus pandemic took hold, and 17 April, new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) show.

articles: Up to one in 17 care home residents may have died since the Covid-19 outbreak started. Why?
name: Up to one in 17 care home residents may have died since the Covid-19 outbreak started. Why?
summary: After 20,836 people died in the five weeks to 17 April, care homes have become the new epicentre of the disease.
first-par: As many as one in 17 care home residents may have died in just five weeks since the start of the Covid-19 outbreak. New data released on 28 April showed that the number of care home deaths has gone beyond “alarming” and is becoming a national scandal.

articles: As many as one in 17 care home residents may have died since outbreak began
name: As many as one in 17 care home residents may have died since outbreak began
first-par: As many as one in 17 care home residents may have died in just five weeks since the start of the Covid-19 outbreak, Nicu Calcea reports. New data released on 28 April showed that the number of care home deaths has gone beyond “alarming” and is becoming a national scandal.

articles: Death rate in most deprived areas double that of richest neighbourhoods
name: Death rate in most deprived areas double that of richest neighbourhoods
first-par: People in the most deprived areas of England and Wales are dying at more than twice the rate of those in the most affluent places, new data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) shows.

articles: Berlin has biggest rise in public transport use and traffic congestion among world cities
name: Berlin has biggest rise in public transport use and traffic congestion among world cities
first-par: Some world cities are seeing an increased movement of people even before lockdown restrictions are eased, our weekly city mobility chart shows.

articles: Renters and the self-employed have taken biggest financial hit from pandemic
name: Renters and the self-employed have taken biggest financial hit from pandemic
first-par: More than half of self-employed workers say their household finances have suffered during the Covid-19 crisis, according to new data from the Office for National Statistics.

articles: Major European cities registering biggest drops in daily Covid-19 cases
name: Major European cities registering biggest drops in daily Covid-19 cases
first-par: The number of confirmed Covid-19 cases is falling in major cities across the world, with countries in Europe registering the biggest drops in daily new cases.

articles: Crime in Northern Ireland falls by a third during lockdown
name: Crime in Northern Ireland falls by a third during lockdown
first-par: Crime in Northern Ireland fell by nearly a third in the five weeks starting 23 March, according to new figures that give us a first glimpse of how the coronavirus lockdown has affected crime in the UK.

articles: Covid-19 cases continue to fall in major worldwide cities
name: Covid-19 cases continue to fall in major worldwide cities
first-par: The number of new daily Covid-19 cases continues to drop in major cities and regions in Europe and the US, while Wuhan has recorded its first new cases since the end of the lockdown.

articles: US daily deaths now double UK, Spain and France combined
name: US daily deaths now double UK, Spain and France combined
first-par: The US recorded 1,156 Covid-19 deaths yesterday, which is more than the reported totals for the UK, Spain and France combined.

articles: Economic forecasts worsen in Europe, Italy faces biggest slump
name: Economic forecasts worsen in Europe, Italy faces biggest slump
first-par: GDP growth forecasts for major European countries and the US have been revised downwards yet again, with France seeing the biggest change from last week.

articles: Number of patients waiting six or more weeks for diagnostic tests highest since 2008
name: Number of patients waiting six or more weeks for diagnostic tests highest since 2008
first-par: The number of people waiting six or more weeks for a diagnostic test in England nearly tripled in March 2020, as Covid-19 saw hospital postpone “non-urgent” treatment.

articles: A&E attendance falls to record low
name: A&E attendance falls to record low
first-par: Attendance at accident and emergency departments in England plunged by more than half in April to a new record low.

articles: Covid-19 cases may be seven times higher than previously thought, ONS testing suggests
name: Covid-19 cases may be seven times higher than previously thought, ONS testing suggests

articles: Covid-19 involved in more than quarter of all care home deaths in recent months
name: Covid-19 involved in more than quarter of all care home deaths in recent months
first-par: Coronavirus has accounted for more than a quarter of deaths in care homes since the start of the pandemic, figures published by the Office for National Statistics (ONS) today showed.

articles: North-west close to overtaking London as epicentre of UK’s Covid-19 outbreak
name: North-west close to overtaking London as epicentre of UK’s Covid-19 outbreak
first-par: The north-west of England is set to overtake London as the epicentre of the UK’s outbreak, latest data shows.

articles: UK cities are awakening as lockdown is eased
name: UK cities are awakening as lockdown is eased
first-par: Walking and driving in the UK surged on Saturday, 16 May – the first weekend day since the government eased lockdown restrictions, new data show.

articles: UK unemployment claims jump 69 per cent in April, a record rise
name: UK unemployment claims jump 69 per cent in April, a record rise
first-par: The number of people claiming UK unemployment benefits increased to 2.1 million in April 2020, a monthly rise of 856,500 and the highest level since 1996.

articles: “Excess deaths“ during pandemic top 50,000 in UK
name: “Excess deaths“ during pandemic top 50,000 in UK
first-par: Around 50,000 more people have died in England and Wales since the start of the coronavirus outbreak than would normally be expected for this time of year, new figures show.

articles: Has there been a “Cummings effect“ on lockdown compliance?
name: Has there been a “Cummings effect“ on lockdown compliance?
summary: The data shows increased mobility during the Cummings story, but it is harder to prove a causal link.
first-par: Did the news of Dominic Cummings’ trips to Durham and Barnard Castle have an effect on the British public’s adherence to lockdown rules?

articles: Why is the unemployment rate so much higher in the US than the EU?
name: Why is the unemployment rate so much higher in the US than the EU?
summary: Differences in working culture and government responses have created a sharp divide. Which way will the UK go?
first-par: It is one of the most famous charts of the coronavirus crisis: a simple bar chart in The New York Times showing unemployment claims soaring to levels that can barely be contained on the front page. In the United States, the unemployment rate jumped from 3.6 per cent in April 2019 to 14.7 per cent a year later. But in European countries — even those hard hit by the virus — it has nudged rather than broken the dial.

articles: Record numbers of people in Britain can’t afford food – lifting lockdown won’t change that
name: Record numbers of people in Britain can’t afford food – lifting lockdown won’t change that
summary: Even before Covid-19 hit, the proportion of households in the UK without the resources to eat was rising.
first-par: It’s been almost 15 weeks since restaurants and cafés closed down across the UK as the country went into lockdown.

articles: Britons are still staying at home because they don’t trust the government over Covid-19
name: Britons are still staying at home because they don’t trust the government over Covid-19
summary: Data shows that UK residents are proving far more cautious about leaving lockdown than their European counterparts.
first-par: For a nation of pub-lovers, Britain is proving hard to coax out of lockdown and back to the bar. Rishi Sunak’s “Eat Out to Help Out” scheme, unveiled yesterday, is another attempt to tempt customers into restaurants, cafes and pubs.

articles: A lifetime of inequality: how black Britons face discrimination at every age
name: A lifetime of inequality: how black Britons face discrimination at every age
summary: From childbirth to retirement, statistics show the lifelong impact of systemic bias in modern Britain.
first-par: Five days after giving birth to her first child, Candice Brathwaite was rushed back to hospital with acute sepsis. For nearly a week, her symptoms — sweating through to her mattress each night, a lump gathering beneath her C-section wound, an inability to breastfeed — had been written off by healthcare professionals. She was advised to “stay off those mummy websites” and stop worrying. This oversight meant she spent weeks in intensive care away from her newborn daughter, Esmé-Olivia, and took nearly a month to recover.

articles: Is the Eat Out to Help Out scheme encouraging unhealthy eating?
name: Is the Eat Out to Help Out scheme encouraging unhealthy eating?
summary: A New Statesman analysis estimates at least 10,667 of the restaurants currently registered are fast food outlets.
first-par: When pubs, restaurants and cafes reopened on 4 July, data showed that most Britons were still reluctant to leave their homes even as authorities assured them it was safe to do so.

articles: Why the coronavirus mental health crisis may not have peaked
name: Why the coronavirus mental health crisis may not have peaked
summary: Nearly one in five people in the UK experienced some form of depression in June, up by 10 per cent the previous year.
first-par: Depression rates have nearly doubled in the UK as the Covid-19 lockdown takes a heavy toll on the nation’s mental health.

articles: Schools are set to reopen but how safe are they from Covid-19?
name: Schools are set to reopen but how safe are they from Covid-19?
summary: Without a significantly improved test and trace programme, reopening schools could lead to a second wave in December.
first-par: Even as the number of Covid-19 cases rises again in several countries, the world’s schools are preparing to reopen their doors.

articles: Data analysis: How the poorest countries are losing out on Covid-19 relief funds
name: Data analysis: How the poorest countries are losing out on Covid-19 relief funds
summary: New Statesman analysis suggests some countries with a higher GDP per capita have been allocated more international funding to fight the virus than poorer nations.
first-par: There is now almost no place in the world untouched by the spread of Covid-19. The global death toll is approaching one million and inequality is rising across the world. International organisations such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank committed at least $48bn in support to more than 100 nations from 10 June, according to the Centre for Disaster Protection. But a New Statesman analysis suggests that among those countries, the richer ones are receiving more money.

articles: A third of UK residents are under local lockdowns – but has this changed their behaviour?
name: A third of UK residents are under local lockdowns – but has this changed their behaviour?
summary: People in most areas under strict Covid restrictions are only marginally less likely to go to pubs, restaurants and supermarkets.
first-par: As Covid-19 cases continue to rise in the UK, millions of people have entered local lockdown. At present, around a third of Britons live under some form of tighter restrictions.

articles: Are pubs and restaurants to blame for the second wave of Covid-19?
name: Are pubs and restaurants to blame for the second wave of Covid-19?
summary: The hospitality industry has been singled out by Chris Whitty for spreading the virus, but the evidence is anything but clear-cut.
first-par: In a webinar on 8 October, the government’s chief medical officer, Chris Whitty, informed MPs that the number of Covid-19 patients in intensive care in northern England might surpass the April peak – and that one of the main culprits was the hospitality industry.

articles: Hate crime is at a record high — but is there more hate, or more people reporting hate?
name: Hate crime is at a record high — but is there more hate, or more people reporting hate?
summary: Police in England and Wales recorded the highest ever number of hate crime incidents in the year up to March.
first-par: Police records of hate crimes have reached a record high, with some 105,090 incidents reported in England and Wales in the year to March 2020. The data – published by the Home Office on 13 October – represents an eight per cent increase on the previous year.

articles: How the UK suffered 50,000 Covid-19 deaths – the highest number in Europe
name: How the UK suffered 50,000 Covid-19 deaths – the highest number in Europe
summary: Only the US, Brazil, India and Mexico have recorded higher coronavirus death tolls than Britain.
first-par: The UK became the first country in Europe to reach the unwanted milestone of 50,000 total deaths from Covid-19 on Wednesday 11 November, when 595 new fatalities were recorded – the highest daily total since the pandemic’s peak in April. According to government figures, this means a total of 50,365 people in the UK have died from the pandemic. Only the United States, Brazil, India and Mexico have recorded higher death tolls globally.

articles: What will a cashless China mean for the world?
name: What will a cashless China mean for the world?
summary: A new Chinese digital currency could help the country forge an alternative to the US-led global financial system.
first-par: At the beginning of the 11th century, China became the first country in the world to officially introduce paper money into circulation. Now, in its latest effort to digitise its economy, it could be among the first to give it up.

articles: Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah and the Great Smog of modern London
name: Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah and the Great Smog of modern London
summary: Nearly 70 years on from the Great Smog of London, air pollution still haunts Britain’s environmental efforts – and its most deprived places.
first-par: On this date 68 years ago, a thick fog was about to descend on London. From Friday 5 December to Tuesday 9 December 1952, a dense layer of smog smothered the capital during a particularly cold spell of weather.

articles: Mapping the unequal impact of Brexit
name: Mapping the unequal impact of Brexit
summary: The New Statesman’s data team has created a Brexit vulnerability index, using data from every local authority to show where the UK economy will be most affected.
first-par: From 1 January 2021, the UK will no longer be a member of the European Union. While the two sides are still negotiating to reach a trade agreement before the deadline, either outcome will have a significant impact on trade, employment, workforce and funding.

articles: How democracy could become one of the pandemic’s lasting victims
name: How democracy could become one of the pandemic’s lasting victims
summary: New research suggests the world has become increasingly autocratic since the start of the Covid-19 crisis.
first-par: Last year, faced with the global spread of Covid-19, many political leaders enacted emergency powers to help tackle the pandemic. In some cases, however, these powers also expanded their personal reach while silencing their critics and disregarding human rights. In Hungary, a “coronavirus bill” was passed that gave the populist prime minister Viktor Orbán near-limitless power to rule by decree. In Kenya, authorities excessively enforced curfews, leading to widespread police brutality and reported deaths. In South Africa, protests erupted after soldiers entered a man’s home and beat him to death under suspicion that he purchased alcohol, which was illegal under lockdown rules.

articles: Covid-19: a tragedy in numbers
name: Covid-19: a tragedy in numbers
summary: Only Belgium, Slovenia and San Marino have recorded higher coronavirus death rates than the UK.
first-par: A figure as high as 100,000 people is difficult to comprehend. One way to imagine it is to think of the total population of the city of Worcester or that of the borough of Woking. It’s more than a fully sold-out Wembley Stadium. It is one out of every 600 people in the UK. And it is more than five times the 20,000 deaths that Patrick Vallance, the chief scientific adviser, suggested would be a “good outcome” last March.

articles: Which councils are hitting their apprenticeship targets?
name: Which councils are hitting their apprenticeship targets?
summary: Our analysis shows some local authorities are better than others.
first-par: L ocal government provides everything from housing to refuse collection. It is also a significant supporter of apprenticeships, hosting thousands each year. Apprentices learn part-time and work part-time as part of a path into a specific job, such as administrator or social worker. Spotlight crunched the data to get a picture of apprenticeships in local authorities.

articles: Pandemic winners and losers: how Big Tech’s gains mask a struggling economy
name: Pandemic winners and losers: how Big Tech’s gains mask a struggling economy
summary: A global lockdown has caused dramatic shifts in the economic landscape and focused markets on one sector.
first-par: For countries around the world, 2020 was a year of unprecedented disruption. The International Monetary Fund has estimated a global growth contraction of 3.5 per cent for the year. But during this turmoil, some of the world’s biggest companies enjoyed significant investment, with huge increases in their market capitalisation and the wealth of their top executives. The picture from the markets looks optimistic – if you look at a few companies.

articles: Britain’s hidden health crisis: How overcrowded housing may be spreading Covid-19
name: Britain’s hidden health crisis: How overcrowded housing may be spreading Covid-19
summary: New Statesman analysis reveals cramped housing conditions could be increasing coronavirus transmission, disproportionately endangering society’s most vulnerable.
first-par: With workplaces, restaurants, gyms and cinemas largely closed for the last year, Britons have spent more time than ever at home.

articles: How much has Brexit cost the UK?
name: How much has Brexit cost the UK?
summary: Two months after the UK’s full departure from the EU, the painful consequences of that decision are becoming ever clearer.
first-par: Nearly all economists agree that Brexit has left the UK poorer, although the full extent of the impact will remain unknown for many years. The recession triggered by Covid-19 has made separating the effects of the pandemic and those of Brexit harder.

articles: UK economic recovery tracker: the effects of Brexit and Covid-19 on jobs, house prices, trade and spending
name: UK economic recovery tracker: the effects of Brexit and Covid-19 on jobs, house prices, trade and spending
summary: We’ve tracked a range of economic indicators to see how Britain is weathering the events of the past year.
first-par: In 2020 the UK economy suffered its worst annual decline in 300 years. GDP fell by 9.9 per cent, the biggest annual drop since the Great Frost of 1709. Britain had one of the worst GDP declines among developed countries – worse than France, Germany or the US.

articles: Why is Israel doing so much better than Chile at coming out of lockdown?
name: Why is Israel doing so much better than Chile at coming out of lockdown?
summary: Both countries have high vaccination rates, but the difference in Covid case rates can serve as a lesson to the UK.
first-par: Up to a few weeks ago, Chile was raking in praise for its vaccination programme. And this praise wasn’t entirely unfounded.

articles: Britain is becoming the sick man of the G20
name: Britain is becoming the sick man of the G20
summary: Our trackers show the UK’s economic recovery will be slower than that of almost any other advanced economy.
first-par: It might take the UK longer to recover from Covid-19 than most other nations, our British economic recovery tracker indicates.

articles: Why India desperately needs more Covid-19 vaccines
name: Why India desperately needs more Covid-19 vaccines
summary: India is struggling with a lethal second wave and only 9 per cent of its population has received at least one vaccine.
first-par: India is struggling to meet its Covid-19 vaccination goals, despite being one of the world’s leading manufacturers. Just 120 million people, or 8.7 per cent of its population, had received one vaccine by 26 April. Just 1.6 per cent have been fully vaccinated.

articles: Prolific yet quiet: Joe Biden’s first 100 days in numbers
name: Prolific yet quiet: Joe Biden’s first 100 days in numbers
summary: The US president has set about reversing Donald Trump’s legacy, but a smaller media profile and split Senate point to challenges ahead.
first-par: Joe Biden became president at one of the most strained moments in US politics. By the time of his inauguration in January 2021, the coronavirus pandemic had killed more than 400,000 Americans and wrecked the economy. Just two weeks before he was sworn in, an angry mob, who were convinced that Donald Trump was the rightful winner of the presidential election, stormed the Capitol to stop the certification of election results.

articles: “It’s our Brexit”: Will low traffic neighbourhoods affect the local election results?
name: “It’s our Brexit”: Will low traffic neighbourhoods affect the local election results?
summary: As Covid-19 restrictions ease and amid talk of a vaccine bounce, road closures across the country could also be driving voters.
first-par: The Manchester inner-city suburb of Levenshulme is on a journey. Its house prices have increased over 50 per cent in the past five years, the disused railway station is turning into a cycle café and co-working space, and the Sunday Times deemed it one of the “best places to live” in 2019 – the same year an off-licence sitting vacant for two years on a street corner transformed into a vegetarian deli and natural wine seller.

articles: Labour struggles as the Tories and Greens surge – the final local election results
name: Labour struggles as the Tories and Greens surge – the final local election results
summary: Keir Starmer’s party lost 326 council seats, while Boris Johnson’s gained 235.
first-par: The Conservatives gained 235 council seats in last week’s (6 May) local elections in England, winning control of an additional 13 councils. Labour, meanwhile, lost one in five of the seats that it previously held.

articles: Pubs and cafés are back – but the UK economy will be slow to recover
name: Pubs and cafés are back – but the UK economy will be slow to recover
summary: Britain’s economic recovery has been muted so far, and a cautious return to retail and hospitality could be slowed by the prospect of another wave of infections.
first-par: The reopening of indoor access to pubs, restaurants, performances and sporting events today (17 May) has been keenly anticipated. The latest step in the roadmap out of lockdown follows celebrations last month after outdoor hospitality reopened on 12 April, but early indicators show customers have been more cautious than images of crowded beer gardens might have suggested.

articles: How the UK became a stage for hate during the Israel-Palestine conflict
name: How the UK became a stage for hate during the Israel-Palestine conflict
summary: Reports of hate incidents against both Jews and Muslims in the UK have increased over the past two weeks.
first-par: Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire on Thursday 19 May after 11 days of a conflict that has killed 230 people in Gaza and 12 in Israel. In the UK, Prime Minister Boris Johnson has welcomed the ceasefire and called for “a durable solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict”.

articles: How the Indian Covid variant has surged in England
name: How the Indian Covid variant has surged in England
summary: The variant now accounts for up to 75 per cent of new coronavirus cases.
first-par: A new strain of Covid-19, first identified in India, is rapidly spreading across England, with the variant accounting for up to 75 per cent of new cases, the Health Secretary, Matt Hancock, has said.

articles: How Joe Biden’s popularity in the UK far exceeds Donald Trump’s
name: How Joe Biden’s popularity in the UK far exceeds Donald Trump’s
summary: The new US president is currently the second most popular foreign politician among the British public.
first-par: In contrast to Donald Trump, an extremely unpopular US president abroad, Joe Biden, who is in the UK for the G7 summit, has inspired confidence among the British public. Figures from YouGov, based on polling between January 2021 and March 2021, show that Biden is currently the second most popular foreign politician in the UK, with over half of respondents (51 per cent) having a positive opinion of him. Barack Obama remains the most popular foreign leader, earning the approval of 71 per cent of UK voters, while Trump remains highly unpopular (with 71 per cent disapproving).

articles: How the G7’s economic power has diminished
name: How the G7’s economic power has diminished
summary: As the group's dominance of the global economy shrinks, is it time to reinvent its membership?
first-par: The G7 has long presented itself as a group of the world’s wealthiest countries, which together account for around half of global GDP. This allows its members – Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US – to claim legitimacy when they make decisions about some of the biggest issues affecting humanity.

articles: UK house prices grow at fastest rate in 16 years
name: UK house prices grow at fastest rate in 16 years
summary: House prices in Britain rose by an annual rate of 13.4 per cent in June 2021, the highest since 2004.
first-par: House prices in Britain rose by 13.4 per cent in June 2021 compared to the same month last year – the highest annual growth rate since November 2004.

articles: Bubble trouble: pupil Covid-19 school absences quadrupled in June
name: Bubble trouble: pupil Covid-19 school absences quadrupled in June
summary: Some schools in England have closed entirely this month as rising numbers of children are sent home and fewer take regular tests.
first-par: There has been a spike in pupils sent home from school in England due to Covid-19, according to the latest official figures.

articles: UK Covid-19 rates are the highest of any European country after Cyprus
name: UK Covid-19 rates are the highest of any European country after Cyprus
summary: Coronavirus cases in Britain have reached their highest level since January with 221,000 in the last week.
first-par: UK Covid-19 cases have surged with 221,000 people testing positive in the UK in the week to 11 July, official figures show. In Europe, only Cyprus has a higher case rate – over 1,000 new daily cases per one million people – compared to Britain’s 461 new cases per million.

articles: How the EU has overtaken the US on Covid-19 vaccines
name: How the EU has overtaken the US on Covid-19 vaccines
summary: More than 57 per cent of EU residents have now received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine.
first-par: After a relatively slow start, Covid-19 vaccination rates have risen across the European Union – and now surpass levels in the United States, official figures show.

articles: Smoking-related cancers are twice as high among England’s poorest
name: Smoking-related cancers are twice as high among England’s poorest
summary: A new report estimates there are some 11,247 smoking-related cancer cases each year among those in England’s most deprived areas, compared to just 6,200 in the least deprived areas.
first-par: Smoking is responsible for more than twice as many cancer diagnoses among England’s poorest residents than among its richest, according to estimates from Cancer Research UK published on Tuesday (3 August).

articles: How the US and the UK accept far fewer Afghan refugees than other countries
name: How the US and the UK accept far fewer Afghan refugees than other countries
summary: The UK took in 9,351 Afghan refugees in 2020, while Germany accommodated 148,000.
first-par: The Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan has prompted the start of a mass exodus of people fleeing the country’s new government. Western countries have announced plans to accept some of these people, with the UK committing to welcome 20,000 people over the next five years, with women and religious minorities receiving priority access to the resettlement programme.

articles: China’s income inequality is among the world’s worst
name: China’s income inequality is among the world’s worst
summary: The gap between the rich and poor in China is almost as huge as in the US.
first-par: Despite the global recession triggered by the Covid-19 pandemic, China has managed to largely avoid the economic fallout. It reported a rise in GDP of 7.9 per cent for the second quarter of 2021 compared to the same period the year before – much higher than most developed nations.

articles: How the NHS now dominates public spending
name: How the NHS now dominates public spending
summary: Health and social care will soon account for 40 per cent of the UK government’s day-to-day spending, up from 30 per cent a decade ago.
first-par: Health and social care spending will soon account for 40 per cent of the UK government’s day-to-day spending, analysis by the Resolution Foundation shows. This figure is a dramatic increase compared with 2004-05, when it accounted for 28 per cent of spending.

articles: Five fossil fuel companies are suing governments for more than $18bn
name: Five fossil fuel companies are suing governments for more than $18bn
summary: Firms are taking legal action after their profits were affected by climate policies.
first-par: Five fossil fuel firms are suing governments in Europe and the US for more than $18.1bn after their profits were affected by climate change policies, research by Global Justice Now shows. The biggest of these lawsuits has been filed by the Canadian giant TC Energy, which operates much of the energy infrastructure in North America. The company is asking for $15bn as retribution for Joe Biden’s decision to revoke the Keystone XL pipeline permit.

articles: Why China’s pledge to end coal funding abroad is a dramatic moment
name: Why China’s pledge to end coal funding abroad is a dramatic moment
summary: Xi Jinping’s country had planned to build more than 56,135 megawatts worth of coal infrastructure by 2050.
first-par: The Chinese president Xi Jinping has pledged to stop building coal energy plants abroad in an effort to tackle climate change. “China will step up support for other developing countries in developing green and low-carbon energy and will not build new coal-fired power projects abroad,” Xi said in a video message at the United Nations General Assembly.

articles: The Universal Credit reduction is the biggest overnight benefit cut in history
name: The Universal Credit reduction is the biggest overnight benefit cut in history
summary: The £1,040-a-year benefit cut is the biggest since the creation of the British welfare state.
first-par: The £20-a-week Universal Credit uplift (£1,040 a year), which was introduced to support people during the Covid-19 pandemic, officially ends today. The change represents the biggest overnight cut in benefits since the creation of the British welfare state, and one of the biggest total cuts, according to analysis by the Resolution Foundation. It will affect some six million families in the UK.

articles: How Covid-19 vaccines have dramatically reduced deaths
name: How Covid-19 vaccines have dramatically reduced deaths
summary: The ratio of deaths to total cases has changed from 3 per cent during the second wave to just 0.3 per cent last week.
first-par: The number of Covid-19 cases in the UK has risen sharply in recent weeks, with Health Secretary Sajid Javid warning that the daily figure could hit 100,000. Despite that, and despite calls from doctors to reimpose some restrictions such as mandatory masks, health minister Edward Argar has insisted the NHS is not yet under “unsustainable pressure”.

articles: Why the world must abandon coal power to avoid climate catastrophe
name: Why the world must abandon coal power to avoid climate catastrophe
summary: Western countries need to completely phase out coal by 2030 to limit global warming to below 1.5°C.
first-par: The world must drastically reduce the role coal plays in generating its electricity if it wants to avoid the worst effects of climate change. Analysis of various scenarios by Ember, an energy data and research company, shows that OECD countries need to completely phase out coal by 2030, with the rest of the world following suit by 2040, if they are to limit global warming to 1.5°C below pre-industrial levels.

articles: Which countries are the biggest carbon emitters in history?
name: Which countries are the biggest carbon emitters in history?
summary: China and India are far behind countries such as the US and UK for cumulative emissions.
first-par: The Cop26 conference ended on Saturday with an ambitious agreement between countries to halve global carbon emissions by 2030.

articles: Exclusive: Tory MPs would be over £1m worse off in six months with Boris Johnson’s second job ban
name: Exclusive: Tory MPs would be over £1m worse off in six months with Boris Johnson’s second job ban
summary: Original New Statesman analysis finds Conservative MPs in political consultancy or similar advisory roles over the past six months earned £1,088,036 between them.
first-par: In the last parliamentary session alone, 42 Conservative MPs earned over a million pounds between them in second jobs that face being banned in the House of Commons.

articles: Where are the people attempting to cross the Channel coming from?
name: Where are the people attempting to cross the Channel coming from?
summary: At least 167 migrants have died or gone missing on the English Channel route since 2014, not counting those who drowned on 24 November.
first-par: More than half of the migrants crossing the English Channel come from Iran, official figures show.

articles: How UK wages are stagnating
name: How UK wages are stagnating
summary: Boris Johnson has promised a “high-wage economy”, but pay growth was flat in the year to October.
first-par: Wage growth continued to slow in October as inflation reached a 10-year high, figures published by the Office for National Statistics reveal.

articles: The Covid-19 pandemic made us fall in love with Christmas songs
name: The Covid-19 pandemic made us fall in love with Christmas songs
summary: Our data team has tracked the performance of nearly 200 merry tunes released since the turn of the millennium.
first-par:
When is it too early to start listening to Mariah Carey’s “All I Want for Christmas Is You”? Never, the
      singer suggests in a
          video she posted on Twitter on 1 November, in which she ceremoniously smashes three Halloween
      pumpkins with a baseball bat that are carved to spell out “IT’S NOT TIME”, as her 1994 hit starts playing in
      the background.

articles: How does the cost of the BBC TV licence compare to streaming?
name: How does the cost of the BBC TV licence compare to streaming?
summary: At £13.25 a month, the licence fee is cheaper than Netflix’s premium tier and Sky’s streaming service.
first-par: The Culture Secretary Nadine Dorries has announced the BBC licence fee will be frozen for the next two years and then abolished from 2027 if the Conservatives are still in power. “The days of the elderly being threatened with prison sentences and bailiffs knocking on doors are over,” Dorries declared.

articles: How Europe is hooked on Russian gas
name: How Europe is hooked on Russian gas
summary: The EU’s reliance on imports of the fuel from its eastern neighbour has only grown since the 2014 annexation of Crimea.
first-par: As the threat of a Russian invasion of Ukraine looms, one of the levers that Moscow has at its disposal is its valuable exports of natural gas. The EU continues to remain overwhelmingly dependent on these exports, even as tensions between Russia and the West have risen in recent years.

articles: How Portugal’s Socialists triumphed in the general election
name: How Portugal’s Socialists triumphed in the general election
summary: The prime minister António Costa has won an unexpected majority after six years in office.
first-par: Portugal’s incumbent Socialist Party won an unexpected majority in the country’s snap general election on Sunday, giving the prime minister a strong new mandate. The election was called after the government lost the support of two smaller left-wing allies, the Communist Party and the Left Bloc, and failed to pass a budget.

articles: Will Ukraine be the source of Europe’s next migrant crisis?
name: Will Ukraine be the source of Europe’s next migrant crisis?
summary: Up to 1.5 million Ukrainians were internally displaced by Russia’s 2014 invasion of the country.
first-par: BERLIN – One of the consequences of a Russian invasion of Ukraine, such as the one Kremlin has threatened for months, would likely be a massive displacement of civilians.

articles: Was Sweden’s Covid-19 policy really successful?
name: Was Sweden’s Covid-19 policy really successful?
summary: The country’s death rate is more than double that of Denmark, the next most affected Nordic state.
first-par: Sweden’s liberal approach to Covid-19 has apparently been vindicated, according to some British commentators. Its death rate, however, compares unfavourably with that of its Nordic neighbours.

articles: How the Russian rouble has plummeted to a record low
name: How the Russian rouble has plummeted to a record low
summary: Following the imposition of Western sanctions the rouble is now worth less than one US cent.
first-par: The Russian rouble fell to a record low today (28 February) following the imposition of more Western sanctions and Vladimir Putin’s decision to put Russia’s nuclear forces on “special alert”.

articles: Russia cracks down on protesters across the country
name: Russia cracks down on protesters across the country
summary: More than 12,000 people have been detained for protesting since Russia's invasion of Ukraine
first-par: The day after Putin ordered his troops into Ukraine, Irina Maltseva was arrested in the Russian city of Ivanovo. The self-employed tour guide had been taking part in a protest against the invasion. “It was broken up by force, even though there was no legal basis for that,” she told the New Statesman. “They were detaining everyone there, including me.”

articles: War in Ukraine threatens to create a global food crisis
name: War in Ukraine threatens to create a global food crisis
summary: Grains, fertiliser and fuel are soaring in price.
first-par: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is threatening food security across the world, with prices for energy, fertiliser and food reaching all-time highs, New Statesman analysis found.

articles: Personal inflation calculator: how do you compare to the rest of Britain?
name: Personal inflation calculator: how do you compare to the rest of Britain?
summary: Our calculator shows how you could be affected by surging prices in the UK.
first-par: Inflation is increasingly driving up the cost of living in Britain, with the latest figures showing an annual increase in prices of 8.8 per cent to July 2022, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). This figure represents the CPIH, which accounts for housing costs, rather than the more widely watched CPI.

articles: Record-high temperatures in Antarctica leave scientists worried
name: Record-high temperatures in Antarctica leave scientists worried
summary: Temperatures peaked at 40°C above their normal level for this time of year.
first-par: An ice shelf in east Antarctica collapsed this month as temperatures reached the highest point in recorded history. The largest fragment of the Conger Ice Shelf, which is about the size of New York City, is now an iceberg, according to satellite imagery.

articles: How the centre-left and centre-right in France collapsed
name: How the centre-left and centre-right in France collapsed
summary: The Socialists and Republicans, the two traditional governing parties, have suffered their worst election results in history.
first-par: The first round of the French presidential election dealt another blow to Parti Socialiste (PS) and Les Républicains (LR), the two traditional governing parties. The latter’s candidate, Valérie Pécresse, finished fifth with 4.8 per cent of the vote, while the former’s candidate, the mayor of Paris Anne Hidalgo, finished tenth with just 1.7 per cent.

articles: How Right to Buy fuelled the housing crisis
name: How Right to Buy fuelled the housing crisis
summary: Many council homes sold through the scheme ended up on the private rental market.
first-par: Boris Johnson is considering reviving the Thatcher-era “Right to Buy” scheme by giving people the chance to purchase the properties they rent from housing associations at a discounted price.

articles: How CEO pay has returned to pre-pandemic levels
name: How CEO pay has returned to pre-pandemic levels
summary: The median FTSE 100 chief executive was paid £3.6m in 2021.
first-par: Chief executives at Britain’s biggest companies are now paid more than before the pandemic, with a median package of £3.6m in 2021, an analysis by the consultancy firm Deloitte has revealed.

articles: How scammers are exploiting the war in Ukraine
name: How scammers are exploiting the war in Ukraine
summary: Spotlight analysis reveals a spike in registrations of domains referencing the conflict.
first-par: On 24 February, Russian troops invaded Ukraine, marking a pivotal point in the conflict which started with Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea, Ukraine’s southern peninsula, in 2014.

articles: How the cryptocurrency market has crashed
name: How the cryptocurrency market has crashed
summary: The main crypto index shows that prices are 72 per cent below their peak.
first-par: Cryptocurrency trading took another hit today, with prices continuing to sink as the buying spree that took prices to record levels goes into reverse.

articles: Software is becoming more interdependent, and that’s a big security problem
name: Software is becoming more interdependent, and that’s a big security problem
summary: Recent incidents have highlighted the risks of relying on a growing ecosystem of third-party software packages.
first-par: On 16 March, 20 days after Russia invaded Ukraine, users of the Vue.js development framework were panicking. Vue is a set of tools that makes it easier for developers to build interfaces for websites and web applications, including at companies like Facebook, Netflix and Nintendo. According to BuiltWith, it powers 19.8 per cent of the world’s biggest 10,000 websites.

articles: Hundreds of Ukrainian families are being left homeless in the UK
name: Hundreds of Ukrainian families are being left homeless in the UK
summary: At least 660 Ukrainian households have found themselves with nowhere to stay.
first-par: Hundreds of Ukrainian families have become homeless after arriving in the UK as refugees, figures released by the Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities show.

articles: Shooting deaths in the US reveal the deadly cost of America’s gun obsession
name: Shooting deaths in the US reveal the deadly cost of America’s gun obsession
summary: There were 39,682 deaths from guns in 2019, the worst rate in the developed world.
first-par: Just a month and a half after an 18-year-old entered an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas on Tuesday and killed 21 people, 6 people have been killed in a mass shooting at an Independence Day parade in Illinois. The United States has the highest share of gun-related deaths among all developed countries, and one of the highest in the world.

articles: Which countries could Putin try to ‘protect’ next?
name: Which countries could Putin try to ‘protect’ next?
summary: The Kremlin has used the pretext of defending Russian speakers to threaten former Soviet states.
first-par: The Kremlin has used the pretext of defending ethnic Russians to attack Ukraine, and to threaten other former Soviet states. Recently it has threatened Moldova, with a Russian commander saying in April that gaining control over southern Ukraine would help Russia link up with the breakaway Moldovan region of Transnistria. Dmitry Peskov, the Kremlin press secretary, claimed in June that Moldova associates its pursuit of EU candidate status, which it was granted on 23 June, with opposition to Russia. “The more they become anti-Russian, it seems to them that the more Europeans should like them. We would really not want this to happen,” he said.

articles: How the rise of buy-to-let landlords fuelled the housing crisis
name: How the rise of buy-to-let landlords fuelled the housing crisis
summary: First-time buyers have been priced out of the housing market by wealthier people.
first-par: In the 20 years from 2000, the proportion of people owning two or more homes more than doubled, according to analysis by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

articles: How UK cash withdrawals have reached a record high
name: How UK cash withdrawals have reached a record high
summary: The cost-of-living crisis has led to a 20 per cent year-on-year rise in cash withdrawals.
first-par: The Post Office handled £829m in personal and business cash withdrawals in July. This represents an increase of nearly 8 per cent compared to the month before, and an increase of 20 per cent compared to the same month in 2021.

articles: Two thirds of UK families to enter fuel poverty by January
name: Two thirds of UK families to enter fuel poverty by January
summary: If annual bills rise to £4,200, 66 per cent of families will be considered fuel-poor.
first-par: Nearly 46 million people in the UK could be in fuel poverty by next January, an analysis by researchers at the University of York has found.

articles: Can your favourite pub afford to keep the lights on this winter?
name: Can your favourite pub afford to keep the lights on this winter?
summary: Business electricity spending is set to rise rapidly in October.
first-par: Businesses’ spending on electricity is set to more than double as a share of all expenditure compared with 2018, New Statesman analysis found.

articles: How much territory does Ukraine control? Use this interactive map to find out
name: How much territory does Ukraine control? Use this interactive map to find out
summary: The New Statesman's interactive map shows the size of Ukraine's occupied territory when compared to other countries
first-par: Editor’s note: The article was originally published in June. It has been updated in light of recent events. Beginning in late August, Ukraine’s armed forces launched a counteroffensive to retake occupied areas in the Kharkiv, Donetsk and Luhansk regions of the country. Throughout September the counteroffensive successfully retook a large area of the east, and in October Ukraine announced gains in its counteroffensive in the south. In an address on 4 October, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky said, “The Ukrainian army is carrying out a pretty fast and powerful advance in the south of our country as part of the current defence operation.”
